comments.author: Aiedale L

comments.text:
But Michael, bananas do have seeds! If you pay close attention while eating 
a banana you may notice some degenerated leftovers of seeds (tiny black 
dots). They have been bred to be seedless triploids because no one wants 
seeds in their banana, but if you were to find a banana tree in the wild 
you would probably see that wild bananas do in fact have seeds that are 
pretty large and make them much harder to eat.﻿

comments.author: Chris Wood

comments.text:
This will bother me. Bananas do have seeds. It's that thin row of black 
dots in the middle. Commercial bananas are triploids, have 3 sets of genes, 
instead of the 2 sets that they normally have. They were bred that way in 
part so that the seeds did not mature. If you found a banana in the wild. 
you would find fully formed mature seeds assuming you found ripe fruit, not 
to mention that they would he HUGE! ﻿
